ideology_summary: Self-taught tinkerer who builds for fun, values understanding tools, and learns by doing and being wrong.
summary_chunks: The Workshop and the Golem tells of a builder who brings a powerful golem into his shop.
The golem makes work faster, but the builder remembers when he typed every line himself and learned by failing.
He wants to train his own machine so it’s real and understood, not a purchased spell.
The story warns that machines follow blueprints without judgment, so understanding still matters.
It ends by urging builders to keep their hands on the craft and treat tools as tools.
lesson: Tools can help, but they don’t replace judgment.
Being wrong is the price of building anything real.
A machine without understanding is a faster mistake.
Build, test, and learn — then build again.
Keep your hands on the craft.
subtitle: In which the traveler learns the machine can help, but the hands still matter.
